DOC.HEADLINE: Norwegian oil production interrupted until at least next week

TEXT.P: Norwegian oil group Statoil said Monday that production on two of its platforms in the North Sea shut down last week because of a gas leak would probably remain suspended until at least next week.

"It is probably impossible to say anything until the end of next week end about the date at which the Snorre A and Vigdis (platforms) will be able to resume activity," Statoil, the operator of the two installations, said in a statement.
On November 28, the company shut down Snorre A after a gas leak was detected. The smaller Vigdis, located near Snorre A and whose production transits Snorre, was also closed.

Norway's oil production has been reduced by some 205,000 barrels per day. The country is the world's third-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia and Russia, with an average daily production of three million barrels.
The gas leak, which could have caused an explosion if the gas had ignited, was sealed a day later and Statoil has since been trying to secure the injection well where the leak appeared.
"We still have a fair amount of work to do before we can resume production," Oivind Reinertsen, a senior Statoil official, said in the statement.
The agency that oversees health and environmental issues in the oil sector, Petroleumtilsyn, must also give the green light for production to resume, which could delay matters even further.
